USER: Write a paragraph about Qin dynasty.

Named for its heartland in Qin state, it arose as a fief of the Western Zhou and endured for over five centuries until 221 BC, when it evolved into an empire following its complete conquest of other rival states, which lasted only until 206 BC. It was established in 221 BC when Ying Zheng, who became the king of Qin state in 246 BC, declared himself the first emperor (Shi Huangdi).
USER: Write a paragraph about The Beatles.
ASSISTANT: The Beatles were an English rock band formed in Liverpool in 1960, comprising John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr. They are regarded as the most influential band of all time and were integral to the development of 1960s counterculture and the recognition of popular music as an art form. Rooted in skiffle, beat, and 1950s rock 'n' roll, their sound incorporated elements of classical music and traditional pop in innovative ways. The band also explored music styles ranging from folk and Indian music to psychedelia and hard rock. As pioneers in recording, songwriting, and artistic presentation, the Beatles revolutionised many aspects of the music industry and were often publicised as leaders of the era's youth and sociocultural movements.
USER: Write a paragraph about Poseidon (film).
ASSISTANT: Poseidon is a 2006 American action disaster film directed and co-produced by Wolfgang Petersen. It is the third film adaptation of Paul Gallico's 1969 novel The Poseidon Adventure, and a loose remake of the 1972 film of the same name. It stars Kurt Russell, Josh Lucas and Richard Dreyfuss with Emmy Rossum, Jacinda Barrett, Mike Vogel, Mía Maestro, Jimmy Bennett and Andre Braugher in supporting roles. It was produced and distributed by Warner Bros. in association with Virtual Studios. It had a simultaneous release in IMAX format. It was released on May 12, 2006, and received mixed-to-negative reviews but was nominated at the 79th Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects. It grossed $181.7 million worldwide on a budget of $160 million; however, after the costs of promotion and distribution, Warner Bros. lost around $77 million on the film, making it a box-office bomb as a result.

answer: Usain Bolt (née Biribianne Johnson; born September 9, 1986) is a Jamaican sprinter who holds the world record for fastest 100 metres time of 9.58s. He was the 100 metres world champion from 2006 to 2009, the 100 metres and 200 metres Olympic champion from 2008 to 2012, and the relay Olympic champion for 400 metres alongside Michael Frater and Asafa Powell. On May 17, 2009 in the World Championships, Bolt surpassed the previous mark of 9.63 seconds, which had been set in the 2008 Olympics, with a run of 9.59s.

USER:
answer: The Heiress (1947 play) is a musical comedy co-by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, based on The Heiress by Henry James. It was designed for Broadway by Claude B. LePetite, with a book by Lindsay and Crouse. The original production opened on January 5, 1947, at the Broadhurst Theatre on Broadway, where it ran for 789 performances and twenty-five previews before closing on April 19, 1950. The opening was directed by Arthur Schwartz, with choreography by Jerome Robbins, orchestrations by Vincent Youmans, scenic design by Joseph Urban, costume design by William Harlen, and lighting design by Kevin Adams. Tony awards were awarded to: Robbins for choreography, and Urban for set design. It is the last play in which Robbins worked as a choreographer. It was directed by Jack Cole at the Winter Garden Theatre in London, and toured for a year. It was revived in the 1950s on Broadway by Rex Harrison, who also played the part of the Count, although never as a straight character. A 1971 revival in London was directed by Harold Pinter. "The Heiress" as a play was made into a film of the same name, in which Katharine Hepburn played Elsie Venner, and John Gielgud played the Count.

answer: Geraldine Chaplin (Geraldine Alice Ngaio O'Sullivan, 16 May 1905 – 24 January 1977) was an Anglo-Irish actor, dancer and fashion designer. answer: The Bridges of Madison County (film) (originally The Bridges of Madison County) is a 1995 romantic drama film directed by Clint Eastwood. The film tells the story of an Iowa farm girl who visits her former fiancée's family, an Italian-American family with the surname (Ventimiglia) matching the town in a fictional region of Iowa. It was produced by Eastwood's Playtone company. The film stars Meryl Streep, Tommy Lee Jones, and Harry Connick Jr., and also features Eastwood's daughter, Francesca. Filming started in 1993 and ended in Northridge, California, on June 1, 1994. It was theatrically released on August 23, 1995. The film was a critical and commercial success, winning the BAFTA Film Award for Best Original Screenplay, and is one of Streep's most critically acclaimed performances. It was also chosen to be included in AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs, one of the American film industry's annual listings of the 100 funniest American films ever made.

answer: Baahubali: The Beginning (English: Serenity: The beginning of the story) is a 2015 Indian epic Telugu-language drama film written and directed by S. S. Rajamouli. Starring S. Prithviraj Sukumaran and Rana Daggubati in the lead roles, the film follows the heroic tale of Mahishmati, Sivagami (Prasanna Venkat), Maharajadhiraja (Siva Rajendra) and Baahubali (Prabhas). In 13th century India, Maharajadhiraja Sivagami Devi faces the challenges of building a nation. She wants to establish peace in Mahishmati, but she faces opposition from those who want the city to be ruled by a military king, and to become a military stronghold. When Baahubali, a ruthless prince of Mahishmati, and his followers kidnap Sivagami, Baahubali takes action by enlisting the help of Sanjay (Manohar Babu), his childhood friend, and his mother, Queen Ganga (Ramya Krishnan).

answer: Harry Potter (film series) was a series of films directed and produced by Chris Columbus, based on a novel series of the same name by J.K. Rowling. The series spans ten films: The Philosopher's Stone (2001), The Chamber of Secrets (2002), The Prisoner of Azkaban (2004), Goblet of Fire (2005), Order of the Phoenix (2007), Half-Blood Prince (2009), Deathly Hallows Part 1 (2010), Part 2 (July 15, 2011), The Deathly Hallows, Part 1 (July 23, 2012), and Part 2 (July 21, 2013). The films have grossed over $8 billion worldwide with $1.38 billion worldwide made by July 2019. The films depict the adventures of 11-year-old Harry Potter, who discovers he has magical powers in the titular Philosopher's Stone. When the stone causes the death of the wizard Albus Dumbledore, whom Harry considers to be his best friend, he is targeted by the evil Tom Riddle (later Lord Voldemort) to destroy Harry's magical friends. Despite opposition from his teachers at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, Harry uses a special egg with Horcruxes in it created by his godfather Sirius Black to fight off the Death Eaters who, through a secret association, are trying to kill him, and Hogwarts itself, for destroying Voldemort's life.

answer: Cult film is the cinematic style or genre of a film that has attained cult status by virtue of either its creative quality or fan following. Films of this type may also maintain a following through their status as a fan favorite, especially amongst a demographic of film-fans. Cult films can be classified as horror films, action, thriller, war, sci-fi or comedy films. Cult films often feature a highly independent sensibility and are almost always made with an eye toward a specific and narrow niche (often underground).

answer: Singapore is an island city-state in Southeast Asia, immediately south of Malaysia. Its main port City is also known as Port of Singapore. answer: Jingle (officially Jingle, the Musical) was a musical written by Stephen Grosz. The story revolves around a Christmas jongleur who enters a contest, "Where Can a Song Go That Will Bring a Tree to Town?", for which he must write a jingle to bring the residents of his town a tree on Christmas Day. He accidentally wins, but the town's Mayor tells him that he can only keep the money if he writes a jingle to keep the snow off the town. He does this, and his jingle soon brings in snow. At the end of the musical, after the mayor has a crisis of faith in Santa and the residents realize they like snow, the jingle is kept, and everyone is happy. The musical won the 1987 Tony Award for Best Scenic Design of a Musical.

answer: John Lennon was an English singer-songwriter, political activist, and philanthropist. He was a member of the Beatles, who became the best known rock group in the world. His solo career produced more than 50 hit songs, including two (In My Life, Imagine), that sold more than 20 million records combined. After his death, many of his songs became anthems for peace, anti-racism, anti-nuclear energy, universal love and environmentalism that can also be heard in more recent albums and live performances. To date, John Lennon has sold more than 500 million records world-wide. For three weeks in December 1970, Lennon topped the charts with Imagine, which was released by Apple Records. As of April 2010, Imagine is the ninth best-selling album by a solo artist and sixth overall.

answer: Prince (musician) is an American songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and the lead singer and primary architect of the Minneapolis music group, Prince & the New Power Generation. Best known for the classic rock "signature songs", "1999", "Purple Rain", "When Doves Cry", "Raspberry Beret", and "Pop Life" and his legendary work ethic, Prince was a prolific musical performer, known for extravagant costumes, stage shows and multi-instrument capabilities; Prince once estimated that his personal music library contained 1,250 musical instruments. By his own estimation, he never gave interviews, although he granted one to Rolling Stone magazine in 1989 and in response to criticism of his work ethic he stated that he would only work every eight years and then only four days a week. Prince once said he would rather be paid late than never. While he was a lifelong atheist, he was also a lifelong romantic and enjoyed dressing up as a gay man and adopting feminine roles during his performances. He is also an innovator and multi-instrumentalist who influenced many musicians including Joni Mitchell, Stevie Wonder, and Morris Day. He is credited with pioneering a new genre of music dubbed 'Aesthetic Funk,' which featured a strong emphasis on complex melodic structures within funk music; his music has become highly imitated, and his records have long been regarded as standards both in and out of funk and in rock, often regarded the "Holy Grail" or "Blueprint" of the genre.

answer: Bal Gangadhar Tilak (Gangadharraj Urs; 3 February 1856 in Ganjeera, Madras Presidency, British India [now part of India] – 29 May 1920 in Pune, British Raj, India [now in Maharashtra]) was an Indian nationalist and social reformer. The political system he advocated was called Tilak Vachan Manch (Hindi: पाल्क वचन मंच; Marathi: [पाल्क] वचान मंच, Marathi for 'Platform of Knowledge'), which is considered to be the forerunner of the Swadeshi, Swaraj, and social reform movements that swept through the Indian freedom struggle during the early 1900s. Some of his most notable political activities were to write a patriotic hymn called "Jana Gana Mana" (Hindi for "Victory to India", written in 1892), for an Indian National Congress session in Mumbai, and to found the Brahmo Samaj. "Happiness in Slavery" was recorded in 1992 by Nine Inch Nails, while the song was available as a B-side on the single "The Hand", issued in 1987. The track was later included in The Fragile album, released the same year, and appeared in the movie soundtrack to the 1994 film The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert.

topic: Back to the Future Part II
answer: Back to the Future Part II is a 1991 action science fiction comedy film written and directed by Robert Zemeckis and produced by Steven Spielberg. Set 22 years after the events of the first film, during Christmas 1985, Marty McFly (played by Michael J. Fox) travels to 1955 in his time machine, an invention of his late great-grandfather George McFly (played by Dennis Christopher), and seeks to save his girlfriend Jennifer Parker (played by Mary Steenburgen). Along the way, he saves the life of her son, who has become an inventor in 1955, and prevents his arrest for the crime in the future of setting off a time machine. His plan goes wrong but he is able to retrieve Jennifer from 1955 to 1985 and her son from the future. As a result of the success of the first film, which was released in July 1985, he finds himself able to make more journeys to the future and rescue people using a DeLorean. He also meets his own ancestor, George McFly (played by Christopher Lloyd), who is now a grown man living in Hill Valley.

answer: Edgar Allan Poe (April 3, 1809 – October 7, 1849) was an American poet and author, widely regarded as among the greatest to have ever written in the English language. answer: Northeast megalopolis is a common feature of the American landscape. It is a highly populated urban area in the northeast of the United States, composed of five major cities (Boston, New York, Newark, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C.) and several surrounding suburbs. The four New England cities (Boston, Providence, New Haven, Hartford) and New York City each account for over a million people, making up over 40 percent of the total population of the contiguous United States.Fluorescent dyes have been of interest for numerous applications such as biological systems, and as reagent in assays and cell culture. However, many dyes tend to have short range excitation and emission spectra (less than about 400 nm and less than about 500 nm, respectively) and often only fluoresce over a portion of the absorption portion of the spectrum. Futher still, some dyes fluoresce in solution but only when bound to a macromolecular target, such as protein, lipid, or nucleic acid. For such applications it is desired to have a dye which fluoresces well in solution and also when bound to a macromolecular target as a substitute for the dye which has short range excitation and emission spectra, or which has low fluorescence in solution. Futher, as these biological applications and assays become more important, it becomes necessary to target a biological molecule which is in a native environment, rather than in a free solution. Still further, it becomes desirable to target a dye which specifically binds to a native biological macromolecule, such as a protein.

topic: The Twilight Saga (film series), The Twilight Saga (film series)
answer: The Twilight Saga (film series) is an American fantasy film series that includes four films in total, two of which were released theatrically in 2008 and 2009 alongside the third and fourth film, The Twilight Saga: Eclipse and The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 1. The five films, which have been distributed by Summit Entertainment, focus on the ongoing story of a group of teenagers who fall in love while under the effects of a furtive curse known as vampirism caused by the eclipse of the sun. The first film Twilight directed by Stephenie Meyer, starred Kristen Stewart and was a commercial success grossed over $724 million worldwide on a $138 million budget. The franchise has continued with a sequel, New Moon and its installment The Twilight Saga: Eclipse and The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 1. Twilight, The Twilight Saga: New Moon and The Twilight Saga: Eclipse remain among the highest-grossing films among the franchise. All three films were nominated for Best Fantasy Film at the 72nd Golden Globe Awards, in addition to numerous wins and nominations.

answer: Transformers: Age of Extinction is a 2014 American science-fiction action film, a film adaption of the Transformers franchise based on the toy line of the same name. Based on the 1984 Hasbro toys, it was directed by Michael Bay (who co-wrote the script with Ehren Kruger). It stars Mark Wahlberg, Nicola Peltz, Stanley Tucci, John Turturro, Helen Mirren, Stanley Tucci, Ken Jeong, Tyrese Gibson, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, Kelsey Grammer, and Burt Reynolds. The film is produced by Michael Bay, his production company BayFilm and Paramount Pictures, and distributed by Paramount Pictures. It opened to positive reviews, with praise for the visual effects, and a strong opening box office performance; it was a box office success, grossing over $1 billion worldwide on a $225 million budget. Although some critics and viewers were concerned at its violence and profane language, others saw it as a return to the "fun" style of the original film series and an example of a "good time" that, unlike previous sequels, did not focus more on action than the story itself. This statement was echoed by critics, who stated that Transformers: Age of Extinction was the first animated film to successfully capture the pure escapist thrill of the early 1980s.

answer: Daniel Craig is an English actor and film producer. He received critical and commercial success in a variety of leading film roles, gaining recognition for his portrayal of James Bond, particularly the first film in the Bond film series, Casino Royale (2006). For his work in these films, Craig won the BAFTA Award for Best British Actor, the Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama, Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role, and the MTV Movie Award for Most Epic F*ck, among other awards and honors.

answer: Nikita (TV series) is an American action spy drama that aired on the Fox network for three years from February 7, 2006, until June 23, 2009, to generally positive reviews. The first-season premiere was watched by 13.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen Media Research, and attracted high ratings in both its first and second seasons. With an average of 10.3 million viewers per episode, it was one of the most successful new shows on American television. The show was primarily set in modern-day Russia with portions set in the United States, including scenes on U.S Naval installations in California and on the California coast which were actually filmed in various locations in Los Angeles County. It starred Maggie Q, Shane West, and Boyd Holbrook as Nikita, a young woman recruited to be an assassin, and who must work to stop rogue KGB officers from enacting an assassination attempt on the world's most powerful leaders.

USER:
answer: Republic of Ireland (also known as "Éire", "Ireland", "Eire" and "Éire") is a sovereign state in Ireland. It is usually described as a country – although its status as a state with internal sovereignty is disputed by Ireland's eastern neighbor, the United Kingdom, which administers it as one of its four constituent countries. According to the 2010 CIA World Factbook, the population of Ireland is 4.8 million[7] while the most recent Eurostat estimates put the population in 2018 at 4.8 million inhabitants or 5.4 million including second generation Irish people. It has a territory of about 5,000 km2 (1,969 sq mi)[8] of which about 4,000 km2 (1,531 sq mi)[8] is land and the remainder water. The island of Ireland was formerly divided into six counties, which in turn were divided into baronies, and later into civil parishes. The modern constitution and the system of government dates from the establishment of the Irish Free State as a dominion of the British Empire in 1922, when 25 of the 32 counties were transferred from the United Kingdom to the state. Irish is an Indo-European language belonging to the North Celtic branch. Ireland is geographically divided into four provinces (counties): Leinster, Munster, Connacht, and Ulster. Irish, Ulster-Scots and Scots are the first languages of large groups of the island's population. The culture of the island has long been bound to the British Isles. It developed from the Gaelic peoples of Ireland, Wales and Scotland, adopting many of their Gaelic traditions, including Christianity, poetry and storytelling. The language influenced the development of English as it is currently spoken worldwide, and is traditionally considered to have had such an influence on Anglo-Saxon, Celtic, Norwegian, Icelandic, Faroese and other languages, as well as many languages of the United States. Irish cuisine includes dishes such as boxty and cabbage and meat coddle, and some traditional dishes are still popular today, such as champ and cabbage, boxty, and Irish stew.

answer: Glen Campbell is an American singer-songwriter and guitarist most prominently known for his pop and country music recordings. One of Campbell's trademarks is his acoustic guitar style, which he was said to have picked up during a session with his parents on their kitchen cabinet. Campbell has also been credited, alongside Jerry Lee Lewis, as a direct influence on rock musician Jimi Hendrix. His first hit was in 1955, the title cut of his eponymous second album. In all, he had 45 Top Ten singles. The Glen Campbell Goodtime Hour was broadcast from 1963-1974 and featured comedy and celebrity guests. It later became The Glen Campbell Country Hour, The Glen Campbell Evening Show, and eventually a syndicated television show. Since the early 1970s Campbell has been primarily active outside the music industry, enjoying a second career in agriculture. He is best known for his signature song, the hit single "Rhinestone Cowboy".

USER:
answer: Afghanistan (/Å kazˈgʋəf/ kɑtzgəhf, kär-[f] zhə-k;[aʊ-]) is a landlocked country in South Asia. Bordered by Pakistan and Iran to the west, China and the former Soviet Union to the north, and the Republic of India to the east and south, Afghanistan is bordered by the Indian Union to the southeast. It includes both the Kandahar and Panjshir valleys and the high Tian Shan range. The country can also be referred to as the "Garland of the Orient" because of its varied topography. It is known as both Afghanistan and Great Afghan because, although it forms a part of the Indian subcontinent, unlike its neighbors, its terrain is much higher and includes the highest mountain range in the world. It is also home to a long, natural border with Pakistan, which is more rugged. The name Afghanistan is derived from the historical region of Afro-Iran, a cultural and linguistic region in Southern Iran, today's southeast Iran. Its location makes it the second-largest country in Central Asia (after Kazakhstan), although it borders some of the world's largest countries, including China, Russia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.

USER:
answer: Hisense was a Chinese consumer electronics and home appliance manufacturer based in Beijing and Chongqing, and owned by the Lumentum Holdings Corporation. Hisense was founded as the Hisense TV Group in 1957, initially specializing in consumer televisions. After the economic reforms in 1982, the company began to focus on consumer electronics as one of its primary businesses. The company became the third electronics manufacturer to have an installed base of more than 100 million television sets during the company's 15 years' existence. Hisense was the country's first domestic consumer electronic company after the opening of China's market to foreign imports. Initially, the company sold televisions and radios in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Southeast Asia, and introduced a number of new consumer products during the 1990s, including a line of appliances (water heaters, air conditioning units, etc.) and audio equipment.

answer: That '70s Show (often stylized as That '70s Show) was an American sitcom that originally aired on Fox from October 19, 1999, through May 18, 2006. answer: Phylogenetic tree or phylogeny, is a graphical representation of evolutionary relationship between species. It is based on Darwinian evolution, with a branch representing several species descending from a recent common ancestor, each branch ending with a leaf representing a descendant species. Phylogenetic trees may be rooted—meaning the ancestor is specified and the branches are arranged in a specific order—or they can be unrooted, with the ancestor left in an implied but unspecified position.

USER:
answer: Social anxiety disorder can be seen in any situation where a human interaction is required. The person may be in a classroom, on a date, during a job/interview, walking down the street, or out in public in a store or mall. The person has feelings of unease in different situations where there are people around. They will feel the urge to avoid being around people or be in the situation when possible by themselves. Social phobia is a psychiatric condition characterized by a fear of scrutiny or scrutiny from another person, in most cases triggered by social situations. People with social anxiety disorder often become frightened or anxious if they are in a large social or public situation and avoid them accordingly.

answer: Midwestern United States is a collective title representing the states of Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Wisconsin. They are collectively known for their history as the "Midwest", their central location in the northeastern United States and North America, and their geographic centrality to the United States. "Midwest", however, as a popular label and nickname, has also come to be used as a way to generalize for many of the states, particularly in sports and travel segments, which are sometimes used as regional shorthand for the American heartland.

answer: Foo Fighters (known to some as Foos) are an American alternative rock band, formed in Seattle, Washington, in 1995 by childhood friends Dave Grohl (lead vocals, drums, percussion), Nate Mendel (guitar), and Chris Shiflett (bass). Initially signed to Columbia Records, Foo Fighters were dropped from the label in November 1999. After changing labels and going independent, they signed to major label Hollywood Records and released their debut album, Foo Fighters, which was certified platinum. To date, Foo Fighters have released eight studio albums, including one EP, four concert films, three soundtrack albums, and one compilation. They are consistently praised for their unconventional blend of metal, blues, alternative rock, glam rock and pop music. The group garnered mainstream success in the early part of the 2000s with the platinum-certified records One by One and Screamers. The band has sold nearly 30 million records worldwide. Other projects undertaken by the band include a side project called Bitter and Blues, a film series known as Metafilm, and several television series, such as Sonic Highways for the NFL Network.

ASSISTANT: The Beatles were an English rock band formed in Liverpool in 1960, comprising John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr. Rooted in skiffle, beat, and 1950s rock 'n' roll, their sound incorporated elements of classical music and traditional pop in innovative ways. The band also explored music styles ranging from folk and Indian music to psychedelia and hard rock. ASSISTANT: Poseidon is a 2006 American action disaster film directed and co-produced by Wolfgang Petersen. It was produced and distributed by Warner Bros. in association with Virtual Studios. It had a simultaneous release in IMAX format. It was released on May 12, 2006, and received mixed-to-negative reviews but was nominated at the 79th Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects. It grossed $181.7 million worldwide on a budget of $160 million; however, after the costs of promotion and distribution, Warner Bros. lost around $77 million on the film, making it a box-office bomb as a result.

answer: Jon Snow (character) or Jon Snow (, born Jon Snow; also referred to as Jon Nieve, Jon Nieve[n], Jon Nieve, or Jon Snow Nieve; (born April 14) is a Game of Thrones, Sansa Stark, the eldest son of Lord Eddard and Lady Catelyn Tully of Winterfell. Having been born in Winterfell, he is a descendant of the old Stark royal family. Jon came to the Iron Throne with Eddard's family, but he was taken from the arms of his uncle Brandon, Lord of Winterfell, by the mad King Robert. His mother Catelyn, being a supporter of Robert's Rebellion, brought him south and turned him into a ward of her sister Lysa Arryn, a renowned healer. Jon fell in love with the Lady Lysa, but Lysa also was a supporter of Robert's Rebellion and was executed after Joffrey's coronation. Jon was raised by Arran, Lysa's brother, and the man who killed her. He would eventually become commander of the Night's Watch after Ragnos's death. His mother, despite her support of Robert, was killed during Robert's coup, and Jon would take on her family's name of Tully.

USER:
answer: Dodecanese (, Dodekanysi, and ΝΝ. DodecaNi, Δίδαθυνi) is a region of Greece comprising the 12 Greek islands of Rhodes, Karpathos, Kasos, Kos, Mykonos, Nisyros, Samos, Syros, Santorini (Thira), Syros, Tinos and Thriasia, also known as the Epirus sinterklos ("Northern Cyclades") and the Peloponnese sinterklos ("Southern Cyclades"). According to some definitions, the main islands, all except Rhodes and Kos, were part of a single administrative region, the Dodecanese, between 1658 and 1912. The Dodecanese, the only region of mainland Greece to remain under Muslim rule, is named for the ancient Ionian city-state of Dodona. Since 1912, it has been governed by the United Nations as the territory of the United Nations Buffer Zone of Occupied Crete, which includes the Karpathos group of islands, the island of Thasos and the island of Girit (Greece). The modern term is attested since the late Byzantine Empire (9th century); the form "ιππουρήωνια τον Διφθάων", meaning  "islands of Rhodes", is from the 9th century.

answer: The Fate of the Furious is a 2017 American superhero action film directed by F. Gary Gray and written by Scott Lang and Chris Morgan. answer: World Science Festival is a series of festivals that includes many major events that are intended to promote science literacy and public understanding and enjoyment of science. answer: The Entire History of You is a 2008 album by English indie rock band Foals. It is the first release by the band on indie record label Hostem Records, following its signing with the record label in 2007 after its success on college radio. The band's previous album was their self-titled debut album which was released in 2001 by Fiction and Rode Recordings under the former's label. The album was recorded at Foals' own studios, West Heath in Hampshire and the Castle of Good Hope in Johannesburg and produced by long-time Foals producer Justin Littler at Rockfield Studios in Monmouthshire, Wales. The album features twelve songs, all of which were written by Foals. All the songs written for the album were written in the first two months of 2007. Littler and the group began working on an album that the band wanted to be reflective and self-reflective and wanted it to be a personal statement in a sense. Prior to making the album, bassist Huw Bunford moved to London to work with the band and spent some time working in another band.

USER:
answer: Scabies is a contagious, erythematous, and crusted skin disease caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei. Transmission occurs mainly through close contact between the infected and susceptible persons, in addition to through fomites (objects commonly used by infected persons). The disease typically presents with a generalized erythematous and crusted rash that may be intensely pruritic. The mites themselves lay eggs on the host's skin, and live for about a week before laying the next generation, also on the host's skin. Infestations are more common in warm, humid climates than in cold or dry climates. The mite's range includes most of the world's people.

answer: Welcome Back (film) is a 1993 drama film directed by Peter Segal based upon the play of the same name premiered at the Royal Court Theatre and directed by Peter Brook. answer: Lightning rod is a tool invented by Samuel Clemens, commonly known as Mark Twain. It was a metal rod that was intended to absorb electricity from the electricity of lightning, preventing it from affecting the electrical equipment. A lightning rod is typically constructed of iron for protection, though other conductive materials are also used.

USER:
answer: Led Zeppelin was an English rock band formed in London in 1968. Originally known as The Yardbirds for their first three studio albums before being renamed with the addition of the "Z" later on in 1969, the group had two lead singers during its lifetime: guitarist Jimmy Page and singer Robert Plant, with bass guitarist John Paul Jones as their manager. The band's name came from a passage in the I Ching about a traveler who comes upon a corpse in the desert and sees that its mouth is shaped like the "Z" on a traffic sign. The two members, especially Page and Jones, have been considered the most prominent members of what is now called the "classic era" of progressive rock. Their sound is characterised by polyrhythmic and densely layered instrumental textures, a focus on dynamic shifting between heavy rhythms and extended sonic excursions that employ improvisation techniques. Led Zeppelin changed the sound of popular music and has been referred to as an influence by other artists such as The Beatles, The Who, and Pink Floyd.

USER:
answer: Central venous catheter (CVC) is a medical device for intravenous infusion of fluids or medications. It has been referred to as the "Everest" of parenteral-drug therapy, because it must be inserted into blood vessels. Many different types of CVC are in common use. The three most common types are external jugular venous catheters, internal jugular venous catheters, and double-lumen venous central catheters. The double-lumen venous central catheter is a catheter designed to be passed over a guidewire, without requiring the removal of the guide wire. This type of catheter is the least invasive, and it is easier to insert. A common problem is the dislodging of the central line after removal of the implant, so the line must be left in place for several days before it can be removed.    assert_equal(self.parser.stream.get_current_source(), None)

answer: North Vancouver (district municipality) is the northernmost of the four urban districts and one of the 30 municipalities that constitute the Vancouver metropolitan area in British Columbia, Canada. Located at the western mouth of Burrard Inlet, North Vancouver lies on the west shore of Burrard Inlet. Vancouver's most-populated city sector, the North Shore, has a large population of people living north of downtown Vancouver. The census tracts that make up the majority of North Vancouver's population are Kitsilano, University Endowment Lands, Kerrs Road, Sunset Beach, and Lynn Valley.

answer: Maria Sharapova (Russian: ; born 10 March 1988 in Nizhny Tagil) is a Russian former tennis player. She is ranked fifteenth in the Women's Singles World Ranking as of April 2013. She reached a career-high of world No. 2 in February 2008, losing to Jelena Janković in three tight sets in the Australian Open final that year, only because of a tiebreak. She returned to the World No. 1 rankings for the second time in March 2008 after defeating Li Na at the Rogers Cup, and the WTA Tour Championships; after a year's absence, she regained her place at No. 1 in early 2009, but lost the ranking back to Janković on August 22, 2009. In 2010 Sharapova regained it after having become WTA World No. 1 since the start of 2010, and she remained at the top for nine consecutive weeks, the longest stretch on the WTA Tour, before losing it to Janković again in April. She was re-ranked World No. 1 again in July 2014. Sharapova won the 2008 Summer Olympics singles gold medal over Vera Zvonareva, but lost against Serena Williams in the 2012 Summer Olympics singles final. She was a member of the Russian women's tennis team that made the final of the 2013 and 2014 Davis Cup and was runner-up with that team in the 2014 World Group semi-final. She was also winner of the singles title at the 2014 Indian Wells/Miami Masters 1000. Sharapova, who was born in Nizhny Tagil, was raised in the village of Krasnogorsk and started playing competitive tennis at the age of six after her brother took her to a tennis camp there. She was the last WTA player to have made a debut in singles during the Open Era.

answer: Charles (14th century or later), Duke of Burgundy, known as the Bold, was a renowned Burgundian nobleman. As the duke's life is unclear due to conflicting accounts, historians and literary scholars have tried to reconstruct what he was probably like and his personality. Scholars and historians generally depict him as a good-looking, powerful, warlike, and ambitious man. He lived his life in the shadow of his father, whose death had left him ruler over only a small portion of the Duchy of Burgundy – and he used those resources to become the lord of much of the County of Artois. Although the only surviving records refer to him as duke of the whole region, historians are also unsure whether the title actually existed during his time, since it was not recorded in contemporary charters. Most historians agree that there cannot have been more than one duke of the whole Duchy of Burgundy at the time and that they therefore had to have been the same man – in such a case, the "earliest known" would make the correct one of the two.

answer: Isabella of France, Duchess of Angoulême, was the queen consort of France and the queen regnant of Navarre. She held the title of Duchess of Angoulême from 1472 to her death in 1494. She was the eldest daughter of Charles VII of France and Isabel of Valois; her siblings included the future Charles VIII. Although much of her reign was spent living away from court in Navarre, she undertook a vigorous program to increase France’s power and prestige, including campaigning in the Hundred Years Wars with England. She married Louis, Dauphin of France, but had no surviving children.

topic: Just My Luck (2006 film), Just My Luck (2006 film)
answer: Just My Luck (2006 film) is a Bollywood romantic comedy film directed by Abhishek Kapoor starring Akshay Kumar and Kareena Kapoor. The film revolves around two friends, Armaan and Preeti, who get married and are separated shortly after. After the separation, Preeti starts living alone in her parent's mansion. On the day of her father's funeral, Preeti and Armaan meet accidentally and get married without consent of Preeti's parents. On their way back to Preeti's home Armaan is involved in a car accident, in which Armaan is killed. The rest of the film follows the journey of Armaan and Preeti as they try to understand each other and find their way back to each other. It tells an old traditional Indian romance story.

answer: Elizabeth Taylor Louise "Liz" Taylor (born October 24, 1932; pronounced [elz-et-te-leez]), nicknamed "Boom", is an American actress, writer, singer, businesswoman, humanitarian, producer, director, and former model. She won three Academy Awards and three Golden Globe Awards, becoming the acting world's highest-earning and highest-paid actress as well as the highest-paid performer of any gender and the highest paid in box-office history. Between 1958 and 1976 her income from film and theatre surpassed all previous earnings made by any of her female co-actors. During a career spanning seven decades, she has starred in around 50 films, but remains best known for her performance as the title character in the eponymous 1958 film, which was nominated for three Academy Awards. The film version is also regarded as one of the classic films featuring the "sexual revolution". Taylor is often cited as a defining icon embodying the transition of Hollywood glamour into superstar culture in the late 1950s and in the early 1960s. She is the highest-paid cast member in film history.

answer: Elton John (born Reginald Kenneth Dwight; June 24, 1948) is an English singer, songwriter, pianist and actor and a member of the Grammy Award-winning British rock band, Elton John Band. During the mid-1970s, John forged a new sound that merged the melodrama and power of rock with his vocal abilities, which were praised for his expressive and "determined" singing. Elton's commercial and critical success began in the mid-1980s with the release of his best-selling albums Captain Fantastic and Goodbye Yellow Brick Road, which won several awards, including two Grammy Awards, two American Music Awards, two BRIT Awards, the Ivor Novello Award for Songwriter of the Year and Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song. Since 1993, John has released 26 studio albums, and is a member of The Rocket Society. Some of his biggest selling songs include "Candle in the Wind", "Can You Feel the Love Tonight" and "Funeral for a Friend". His latest album is Wonderful Crazy Night, released in 2020.

answer: Room (2015 film) is a psychological thriller which premiered at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival and was shown in other film festivals. USER:
answer: Her (film) is a 2013 American science fantasy romance film written and directed by Spike Jonze. The story focuses on Theodore Twombly (Joaquin Phoenix) and his relationship with his artificially intelligent operating system, Samantha (Scarlett Johansson). After meeting Samantha in Thailand, Theodore builds up his life around her and they fall in love. But their relationship begins to change when Samantha falls in love with a different man, whom she plans to meet in New York City. When their relationship intensifies, a series of events brings the two's worlds crashing down, and Theodore must decide whether to sacrifice his own happiness to save Samantha or just simply be with her.

answer: Prison Break is an American television series created by Paul Scheuring. It was originally broadcast by Fox from September 23, 2005, to March 21, 2010, lasting for eight seasons and a total of 110 episodes. The series was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award in the category of Outstanding Drama Series and for six Golden Reel Awards, winning a Best Sound Editing (Music) award in 2009 for 'The Storm'. In 2011, Netflix released the first series' DVD box set on December 8, 2011, to positive reviews from the general public and critics alike, with the series being cited as "a series that fans will watch over and over again". The series also became the first show to be renewed for a sixth and seventh season by Netflix after its fifth season, even though a DVD box set of season four was released by 20th Century Fox on December 11, 2011. In 2016, Fox aired a third season of the show. In 2018, in the midst of its seventh season, Fox aired a feature-length film that served as both a prequel for the events of season six, and an epilogue for the events of season seven and all episodes in season eight, titled Prisons can be a lot of things - a place, an institution, a system - but the most effective instrument of control is not so much a lock on the door, or a barbed-wired fence around the yard, but the constant drip, drip, drip of psychological torture and degradation.

USER:
topic: Modern liberalism in the United States
answer: Modern liberalism in the United States is a philosophy commonly associated with the economic and industrialist philosophy of a capitalist society that emphasizes the moral obligation of state and corporate officials to the general population. Its first identifiable manifestation was the New Deal reforms of the 1930s, which included various programs to combat poverty, improve healthcare, build public infrastructure, and regulate businesses. After World War II, as the United States faced issues with the loss of economic infrastructure and the growth of poverty among its population, modern liberalism grew in prominence and influence. The most visible modern liberals were the New Deal Democrats led by Harry S. Truman, who became the 36th President of the United States and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who became United States Senator for New York in 1951 until his death in 1972; they were followed by Democrats such as Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Lyndon B. Johnson, and Nelson A. Rockefeller. Beginning in the 1960s, a new group of progressive Democrats emerged, which included other politicians such as George McGovern, Edward M. Kennedy, and Eugene McCarthy, often termed the "New Consensus", although the majority of them shared many of the goals of the New Deal. However, after the Watergate Scandal and other political infighting and scandals which dominated the 1970s, the modern liberalism movement became severely weakened, although it survived and remained influential into the 1980s.

answer: Three Men and a Baby is a 1957 American motion picture written and directed by Leo McCarey and starring Spencer Tracy, Kim Novak and William Reynolds. It tells the fictional story of Charles Loring Brace, his wife Anne and her lover Henry Horatio Mann. The story's plot is set in the late nineteenth century and is loosely based on the true experience of the real-life reformer Charles Brace. It deals with the relationship between the three people and Charles Brace's efforts to educate young women on the virtues of being a mother. It stars Spencer Tracy as Mann, William Reynolds as Brace and Kim Novak as Anne, who plays a pregnant socialite. Tracy's performance earned him a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Actor.

topic: The Lion King, Walt Disney Animation Studios
answer: The Lion King is a 1994 American animated musical film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures. It is the second of two Disney direct-to-video sequels to The Lion King (the other being The Lion King II: Simba's Pride), the sequel to the Disney animated film The Lion King (the first Disney film to ever be animated entirely in computer imaging). The film was directed by Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff, co-directed by Kirk Wise, and written by Linda Woolverton. It features the voices of Donald Sutherland, Jeremy Irons, Timothy Spall, Rosie O'Donnell, Jodie Foster, Nathan Lane, Nathan Lane, Rowan Atkinson, Ernie Sabella, Donny Osmond, Elton John and James Earl Jones. It was released in theatres on November 22, 1994, and has grossed over $600 million and become the third highest-grossing animated film of all time.

answer: Joaquin Phoenix is an American actor and model. He is known by the mononym Joaquin. Phoenix was born in Palo Alto, California, the son of actors John Marley Phoenix (1950–1985) and Lois Faye Henner (born June 1, 1949), the eighth of eleven children. Before becoming a model, Phoenix attended Valley Country Day School. He is a former cast member of the children's television series The Wild Thornberrys and The Thirteenth Year. Phoenix made his acting debut in the movie A Walk on the Moon (1999), playing a mentally disturbed man. His debut film as a leading actor, Sleepwalker's Way (2001), was commercially unsuccessful and he left the film industry for a period of three years. Upon his return to the industry, he received positive critical reviews for his leading roles in the gangster biopic Gangs of New York (2002), the independent film I'm Not There (2007), the biopic The Last Airbender (2010), and the historical drama The Master (2012).

answer: Patch Adams (film) is a 1998 American family comedy-drama film directed by Tom Gillingan and written by Michael Mayer. The film, adapted from Stephan Elliott's 1993 bookPatch Adams: A Stitch in Time, stars Robin Williams as the title character, a physician whose desire to help people conflicts with his own inability to control his neuroses. The film explores concepts of medical ethics such as life extension, and touches on some of the issues in contemporary society such as poverty, sexuality, and AIDS. The film received mostly negative reviews from critics. The success of the film led to a three-hour television miniseries adaptation in 2003. Patch Adams: The Movie was released in May 2004.

topic: Modern liberalism in the United States
answer: Modern liberalism in the United States is a form of liberalism associated with a social liberalism that has been a constant factor in the politics of the Democratic Party and a significant factor in American society. In general, liberalism in the United States (as in much of Western Europe) is identified with social and economic liberalism. American liberals are usually associated with social and civil liberties, civil and political rights, multiculturalism, multicultural rights, and LGBT rights.

answer: Boeing 777 or Boeing 787 Dreamliner is a twin-aisle jumbo jet with Rolls-Royce RB211-535 engines manufactured by Boeing. It was developed from Boeing 767-300ER with a longer range and redesigned interior. The first Dreamliner, named 777-300ER, was delivered to Singapore Airlines on 21 July 2004 and to Japan's All Nippon Airways on 11 May 2005. Boeing also sells the previous generation of the Dreamliner, the 767-400ER, which has similar specifications to 777-300ER but with smaller wings and the stretched fuselage. The 777 has been the world's most successful commercial airliner in the past seven years. The first 777-300ER took first place in a new airline efficiency award in the 2007 World Business Traveller Top 100 Awards. This plane is one of the safest wide-body passenger jets when compared with previous Boeing models, such as the Boeing 747 and the earlier Boeing 767. The 777 is also a leading-edge airplane in safety, passenger space and cargo volume.

answer: Grace Jones (born Daphne Ozeri[1] on September 22, 1949) is a Jamaican-British singer and actress. USER:
answer: Victor Hugo was a prolific French writer born in 1802 and is widely known by one name: Victor Marie Hugo. He remains the most translated of writers in the world in terms of the number of editions of his works, and he remains widely admired internationally for his romanticism, epic storytelling, and moral vision. A prolific writer in the nineteenth-century Romanticism and Realism styles, Hugo's style was known for being both poetic and powerful, as well as being an inveterate social critic, a gifted dramatist, and an impassioned political activist. Hugo believed in the political efficacy of literature and his work was strongly influenced by the French Revolution and classical French literature. He is best known of his popular works Les Misérables (1862) and Les Contemplations (1863). Hugo was also a prolific playwright, writing many of the most prolific dramas in the French canon. Among other major works are Notre-Dame de Paris, Hernani, Ruy Blas, and Cromwell. A number of his famous stories have been adapted into films, notably one of the most translated authors in the world.

answer: Isabella of France (1245–1270) was queen consort of France by marriage to Charles IV. Along with her first husband, Peter of Courtenay, she was involved in several conspiracy theories, most likely with the purpose to remove the feudal control of the king by the nobility of the Holy Roman Empire. During the Hundred Years War, she was accused of being the mistress of Geoffrey V, duke of Brittany, and of having attempted to obtain the throne of England by taking his son prisoner, although this is regarded as a legend. The chronicle of Matthew Paris reports that she was murdered by her husband on their return from a pilgrimage when he turned suddenly on her with his sword.

USER:
answer: Major League Soccer (MLS), sometimes called "World soccer" to distinguish it from the United States Soccer Federation, is a professional soccer league in the United States and Canada, sanctioned by and operated under the auspices of the U.S. Soccer Federation, an organization within the United States Soccer Federation. It is the second most popular club sport in the United States, after the National Football League. It is among the world's top soccer leagues. Soccer in North America dates back to the late 1880s, when the United States Soccer Football Association was founded, and Canada entered the federation in June 1892. The first soccer World Cup was held in conjunction with the 1904 Summer Olympics in St. Louis, Missouri and featured both the United States and Canada. The MLS was formed in 1996 as an alternative to the existing North American Soccer League and United Soccer League competitions. Before the 1998-1999 season, the new league absorbed the existing USL; by the end of the season, the MLS had twenty-six teams, and had grown rapidly to four more by the end of its first season. Major League Soccer adopted its present name that season, as MLS Soccer was not consistent with the league's branding. The league has since had an official logo and a consistent brand, as well as several name changes. In 2001, a division of MLS based in the southern United States was renamed as a result of sponsorship deals with car manufacturers Hyundai (which sponsored the San Jose Earthquakes) and Dodge (which sponsored the New England Revolution).

USER:
answer: Iran (;  ˈɪɑnə or ˈaʊənə; Persian: ايران‎ or əran) is the most extensive of several great ancient Iranian empires, located primarily along the southern shore of the Caspian Sea, with one of its capitals at Nineveh. After the fall of the Achaemenid Empire in 330 BC, the nation was split into competing kingdoms, with the Sasanian Empire being the last Iranian Achaemenid Empire or Persian Empire to rule until the late 8th century AD. During the Sasanian and early Islamic eras, Iran was variously conquered by a number of non-Iranian powers, including the Romans, Parthians, Kushans, Seleucids, Byzantine Romans, and Arabs, among others. The Islamic conquest of Iran was achieved by the Islamic prophet and one of the most important caliphs in Islam, Muhammad, who began to assemble the Muslims as a state in 634 and captured the Abbasid capital of Baghdad on August 29, 630. Most of the non-Muslim Persians of Iran were either killed or resettled in the Ottoman, Safavid, Afsharid and Zand dynasties of Iran from the 13th to 19th centuries, although a Persian-speaking elite class survived in Iran. This elite class later came to be known as the Qajar dynasty, the last dynasty to reign in Iran before the rise of the Pahlavis in the 19th century. Persians or Iranians (, Pūsistānī or Pūrsīstanī) are the largest ethnic group in Iran, comprising over 85% of the nation's population. Persian culture has been influential in the development of Iranian society, politics, and art and the spoken Persian language is the first language of approximately 85–90 million people, making it the third most widely spoken language in the world.

answer: Massachusetts is a state located in the Northeastern portion of the United States. It is the most populous of the state-level divisions of the United States of America. As of the 2010 U.S. Census, the population of the state is 6,973,491. It is named after the Massasoit, an indigenous leader of the area's first recorded European settlement. The name Massachusetts comes from Massachusett (), a name based on Massasoit's native village in the Pawtuxet Valley (massachusetts being the local Massachusett word for "great") of what is now the city of Providence, Rhode Island. Massachusetts is the sixth most extensive and the fourth most populous of the 50 United States. Its capital and largest city is Boston, and the state's other major city is Worcester.

answer: Are You Experienced was the third studio album by American psychedelic rock band Captain Beefheart and the Magic Band. It was released in 1970 on the Warner Bros. label and features several unconventional musical techniques. The album was recorded in a week at a ranch in Baja California, Mexico, and released to critical acclaim for its unusual sound. The only previous album by Captain Beefheart and the Magic Band had been the poorly received Safe as Milk, which was the band's last fully completed album. The group had parted ways after recording its first album two years earlier, as drummer, singer, and songwriter Zoot Horn Spoon left to be replaced by David "Ned" Grohl.

answer: System of a Down is an American alternative metal band formed in San Jose, California in 1996. With its influence over contemporary alternative rock, their most mainstream-defining album, Steal This Album! is widely considered as one of the greatest albums of 2000.

answer: Apollo 11 was the designation of the United States' first manned mission to the lunar surface, launched by the Saturn V rocket from Launch Complex 39 LC-39, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, on July 16, 1969 at 9:56 am EDT (13:56 UTC).[7] Following its successful landing on July 24, 1969, astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to walk on the Moon.[8] During its mission to the Moon, the spacecraft orbited the Earth 72 times en route to the Moon, completing 36 orbits. USER:
answer: Andy Warhol ( born Andrew Warhola; June 8, 1928, in New York City ) was an American photographer and conceptual artist who helped to define pop art and become the first artist to develop a popular following. During the 1950s Warhol studied art in New York and enrolled in the Art Students League. Before joining a group of artists to work for Jack Kerouac's Beat Generation magazine, The Beat, he became an assistant to Roy Lichtenstein. In 1961 he began a series of silk-screen portraits of what he called his "Campbell's Soup Cans" and in 1965 he used the technique to print the now-iconic portrait of Marilyn Monroe, The Marilyn Diptych. Among his most iconic works is the 1967 painting of soup-can soup cans, "Chelsea Hotel". Warhol would die in 1987.

answer: Marilyn Monroe is an American actress. At 18, she starred in the critically acclaimed Bus Stop, made her screen debut in TheAsphalt Jungle, and appeared in such popular films as How to Marry a Millionaire, Some Like It Hot, Gentlemen Prefer Blondes, The Prince and the Showgirl and None But the Lonely Heart. Monroe's life and career were followed by the media worldwide as one of the 20th century's greatest icons of sex and style.

USER:
answer: International Space Station (ISS) is a space station that allows astronauts to conduct scientific experiments in outer space. It functions as a laboratory where astronauts and cosmonauts conduct experiments and conduct research. It also is used as a communications relay station and is the world's largest man-made structure. The station is located in low Earth orbit, approximately  from Earth's surface, and is part of the space station architecture developed by the space agencies of the member states of the Russian Federal Space Agency (RKA) and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). The International Space Station is the largest man-made object orbiting the Earth, and the second largest artificial object in orbit. It was launched in November 1998 by the Russian mission Soyuz T-11, which was flown under contract to the United States. The first space-born crew consisted of NASA astronauts William O. Cunningham, Greg Newburn, Robert L. Crippen, George A. Paton and U.S. Air Force Colonel Michael W. Smith. It was the second crewed space station following the Soviet Salyut 6 from 1971 until it was torn from the orbit by an onboard problem in 1991.

USER:
answer: Meghan McCain is the daughter of former Republican Senator and 2008 Presidential Candidate John McCain, and the sister of former United States Senator and Republican presidential candidate from Arizona Sarah Palin. She served as a cohost of The View. When her father took over the chairmanship of the 2008 Republican National Convention, she moderated a prime-time debate between presidential candidates John McCain and Barack Obama, the event known as the 2008 "Family Values" Debate. During the debate, she stated that while she supported Obama, she did not endorse him by name, as she felt Democrats would be able to win without her endorsement at the ballot box. Following her father's presidential loss to Obama, she wrote a book about her efforts and accomplishments as a young mother, her political career, and her life after the election in her 2009 debut, The Outlaw Journal of a Female President, and has since participated in subsequent campaigns and political events, becoming the most active, high-profile conservative in the Republican Party following her father's defeat in the 2010 General Election.

answer: Boeing 737 is a Boeing jetliner and the largest member of the Boeing 737 series. Its fuselage is built from rolled titanium that is welded into a large seamless skin, bonded to a metal honeycomb core. It consists of two sections that can be separated hydraulically to allow access to the airframe and engine. The wingspan is 75 to 90 feet. The cabin is pressurized, while all but the last two rows of seats are fully convertible. It has a standard length of 38 feet, 10 inches (11.8 meters), a height of 11.4 feet (3.3 meters) and a width of 7.6 feet (2.3 meters). The first customer was Air India, with deliveries beginning in March 1969.

answer: Nikola Tesla (July 10, 1856 – January 7, 1943) was a Serbian-American scientist and electrical engineer who is often referred to as the "father of modern electricity". After inventing what are now known as electric induction motor and incandescent light bulb, he also discovered the principles of electron and radio-frequency technologies. While building many scientific works, he was a well-educated and self-taught person. Tesla made various important inventions ranging from motor control and alternating-current power system to wireless communication, which were used in a wide variety of industrial and military applications as wireless technologies developed. In order to develop alternating-current power system that could solve the problem of short circuited power and high voltage, he invented the AC induction motor in 1890.

USER:
answer: Ilkhanate or Ilkhanate of Iran, was the dynasty of Iranian people of Mongol ethnicity that ruled from 1335 to 1501. It was an offshoot of the Chagatai Khanate, but came to power with the fall of the Yuan dynasty, as both are offshoots of Mongol khanates. They eventually dominated almost the entire Eurasian landmass except for Russia until the fall of the Mongols themselves in the middle of the 15th century. The Ilkhanate was also known as Great Mongol Empire or Khitanian Empire. "Ilkhan" literally means "protector of the people"; the Ilkhanid dynasty was founded in 1335 by the Yuan dynasty Mongolian general Abu Sa'id of the Chaghatai Khanate as a Mongol-controlled protectorate of Iran during the breakup of the Chagatai Khanate. In the late 14th century, the Ilkhanid ruler Togha Temür declared independence from the Yuan dynasty. Following the fall of the Yuan in the middle of the 15th century, the Ilkhanid Empire continued its independence after the downfall of the Mongols, as part of the Ilkhanate of Iran until it was conquered by the Timurid dynasty in the early 16th century.

Blair was First Lord of the Treasury (as Shadow Minister for Business, Enterprise and Regulatory Reform) from 1997, Chairman of the Conservative Party from 2001 to 2006 and Leader of the Labour Party from 1994 to 2005. He served as the UK's Prime Minister from June 1998 to June 2007. His career as a politician began in 1974, as parliamentary secretary to the Chancellor of the Exchequer under Margaret Thatcher. He was elected leader of the Labour Party in 1994, and, from 1996 to 2001, he served as Home Secretary, before being appointed Prime Minister by the Leader of the Opposition, Tony Blair. His term as Prime Minister is also notable in that he became the first politician to appear on a national television programme, giving an interview to John Cole on BBC1's Panorama on 27 August 2003.

answer: The Hundred-Foot Journey (film) (or The Happy Crane, ; in China also named 零十英呎) is a 2010 French-Canadian romantic comedy-drama film, based on the 2007 novel of the same name, by French writer Jules Verne. Directed by Lasse Hämäläinen, the film had its premiere at the 59th Berlin International Film Festival. It was released in the United States on May 30, 2011. It is the first adaptation of Jules Verne's novels in over 20 years that had its premiere at the Berlin International Film Festival as of 2010. The Hundred-Foot Journey explores the story of the Chinese American couple, Li Siuwai (Gong Li) and Li Ying (Diane Kruger), who attempt to move from France to China for better opportunities in their lives. The Hundred-Foot Journey is filmed in China, France, and Canada. In the film, Siuwai and Ying fall in love and marry after a whirlwind courtship. They decide to move to his native country, Beijing. But their marriage is hampered by Li Siuwai's family, who wants him to go back to France through business interests. Ying, who is pregnant, is forced to leave Siuwai in Beijing. They then reunite in France after Siuwai's family accepts Ying back and they decide to stay in China.

It was founded on February 15, 1932 by Harland Sanders, a Kentucky native who sold his fried chicken recipe to open a small diner in Corbin, Kentucky. The chain was first named Kentucky Fried Chicken, and later shortened to KFC. It is the world's third-largest fast food chain measured by annual sales, with over 19,000 restaurants in over 100 countries, including more than 1,600 in China. Originally incorporated within the state of Ohio, KFC's headquarters and most of its operations were based in Louisville. The headquarters moved to an office park outside Louisville in 2015 which was subsequently abandoned at the end of calendar 2019 due to a lease issue. In 2010, the corporation had annual revenues of $3.8 billion and gross profits of $1.6 billion.

He is one of the most commercially successful musicians in history, having sold more than 600 million records worldwide. More than 1.6 billion people worldwide have heard of him, and he is considered by some as the biggest cultural icon of the 20th century. Presley became the central figure of the rock era, as well as a key influence on the rock-influenced styles of the following generation of musicians. Presley was the leading figure in rock 'n' roll from the mid-1950s until the mid-1960s. He also had numerous other musical genres on which he has exerted a great influence, most notably gospel, rhythm and blues, rock and roll, and country music. The artist also recorded and acted widely in motion pictures, and his career was extended through a 1969 film and a 1972 musical soundtrack, among many others. Presley's career produced 37 studio albums, 25 Christmas albums, 27 live albums, 25 soundtracks, four compilations, 24 compilation or best-of albums, and 16 cover-art projects. He was one of the best-selling music artists of all time, with estimated sales of 75–85 million, and he ranked second among the best-selling music acts during the 20th century behind the Beatles. He also tops the Billboards list of best-selling albums of all time, with 24 million copies of Elvis: The Aloha Way. He has also been named among the four-most influential artists of the 20th century by the American media. In 2004, Presley was inducted in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame by the United States National Recording Preservation Board. He appeared in a total of 50 motion pictures, including 36 in colour, including the Academy Award–winning film Viva Las Vegas.

USER:
answer: Paul Pogba (born 30 October 1990 in Le Touquet, Pas-de-Calais) is a professional footballer playing as a central midfielder for the French club Manchester United. He came through the ranks as a youth player with the Le Havre club. Pogba later played for the youth-team of Auxerre, where he then signed for Ligue 1 side Olympique Lyonnais. Despite being named in the France national squad, he did not debut, however, and instead went on loan to Stade Brestois 29 in the 2009–10 season. Pogba then moved to Italian Serie A club Juventus F.C. In the 2011–12 season, he scored the opening goal in Juventus' win over English Premier League club Manchester United in a 1–0 friendly match. He made his club debut in the following season, however, on 25 September 2011. Pogba was a regular in the Juventus first-team squad and became a key member of the side, making over 100 appearances in all competitions during his first two seasons. He scored his first goal in the UEFA Champions League against Marseille in the 2011–12 season which saw Juventus go on to win the competition. On 31 August 2013, he joined the French club Lille OSC on loan for a season. With Lille, he lifted the 2013–14 UEFA Europa League trophy after scoring as a substitute in a 3–1 victory over Olympique de Marseille in the final. Pogba moved to Manchester United in July 2016 for an initial £100 million transfer fee and signed a long-term deal with the club in the following month. After the departure of former manager Louis van Gaal in November 2016, Pogba found his role reduced and did not play or train with the first-team thereafter. Pogba returned to action in February 2017, when he made his first and only appearance of the season, as a substitute, in a 1–0 victory over Stoke City as Manchester United advanced to the 2017 FA Cup Final. On 2 July 2017, he signed a new five-year contract with United. Pogba was a regular at Premier League matches during the 2017–18 domestic campaign, making 31 appearances and scoring 13 times. On 12 January 2020, it was announced that Pogba was released from Manchester United, with Juventus also expressing an interest in buying back his contract.

answer: Serena Williams is an American tennis player born on December 17, 1982 in her hometown of Compton, California. At the age of eight, she began playing tennis, later being introduced to coach Ann Treacy, who guided Williams to first become a national tennis amateur, then a professional. After becoming one of the youngest college singles players and one of the top players in women's college tennis, Williams moved to the professional circuit as a single player. As a professional on the WTA Tour, she has won twenty Grand Slam singles titles and eighteen Grand Slam doubles titles, and is the most successful player of all time with a grand slam in singles and doubles. Williams is the most successful black female tennis player of all time. She became the youngest ever female tennis player to reach singles world number one when she did so at the age of 19. She is the recipient of two sports awards, having been named the United States' most outstanding amateur athlete in 2002 and 2003. In 2004, Williams became the first tennis player to reach the US$10 million mark in career earnings.

answer: Paris (mythology) is the legendary first capital of the legendary city-state of Troy. Paris was so named because, according to ancient Greek legend, the Greek hero Odysseus was once hidden in his home in the city during the Trojan War. After a lengthy search, Odysseus' friends and family decided to name a new village Paris, after the Trojan leader, because of a man they believed to be Odysseus' father. However, according to the alternative story, which has become popular since the end of the 20th century, Odysseus fled from a home with a Spartan mother and returned to his family. In this version, named the Trojan War, Paris was the leader of the Greeks, and their first capital, because of the belief that the inhabitants of Troy gave Odysseus shelter.

USER:
answer: Kitti's hog-nosed bat (Bassariscus gularis) is a species of New World bat. They are native to much of Central and South America. Kitti's hog-nosed bat is one of the most widely distributed species of Central America. It is a highly territorial animal preferring dense forests, second and third growth forest, and open areas where it roosts in caves, hollow trees, and on cliff faces. Kitti's hog-nosed bat is not commonly found in houses, preferring to remain in the dense forests. It roosts in cavities such as bat-chamber crevices and tree-cavities where they form sleeping clusters from one to a hundred or more individuals. Kitti's hog-nosed bat is a social bat with a solitary nature, most of their colonies are composed of just one or two females and their young in the case of roosting in cavities. They give birth to 2-6 altricial kittens in the summer and have a gestation period of about 11–12 days.

answer: Pink Floyd is a band formed in 1965, in London, England, by singer/bassist/songwriter Syd Barrett, guitarist/songwriter/keyboardist David Gilmour, and drummer Nick Mason. The band achieved international success with the progressive psychedelic sound of its first four studio albums, The Piper at the Gates of Dawn (1967), Atom Heart Mother (1968), The Dark Side of the Moon (1973), and Wish You Were Here (1975), all of which charted within the top 10 of The Billboard 200. The band's fifth studio album, Animals, was released in 1979 and reached number 17 on Billboard, and included the hit single "Shine on You Crazy Diamond". Pink Floyd broke up in March 1986, but reunited in 1994 on the recommendation of Gilmour. The reunited Pink Floyd released two more studio albums, The Division Bell (1994) and A Momentary Lapse of Reason (1997), and a live album, Pulse (1997). The band's eighth and final album, The Endless River (2014), is a concept album about Syd Barrett's time with Pink Floyd.Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and subsequent intracranial hemorrhage: case report and review of literature.

USER:
answer: Venus is the second-brightest natural object in the Solar System, after our Sun. Like Earth, Venus is a terrestrial planet that orbits very close to the Sun, completing an orbit in about 225 days, as compared to 225.8 Earth years. Because of its proximity to the Sun, Venus is strongly heated and all but saturated with atmospheric gases. Venus is tidally locked to the Sun. So its day is very long, taking 118.7 Earth days to complete. Its night is very brief – 6 hours, as opposed to Earth's 24 hours – but the planet completes one rotation on its axis in a time considerably shorter than Earth's. Venus's surface temperature averages about 835 kelvin, making it the hottest planet in the Solar System, although the surface is heavily laden with sulphuric acid rain. The very rapid rotation of the planet results in a dense atmosphere about 50 km (100,000 ft) thick of super-heated gases held aloft by the Sun's gravitational attraction.

answer: Arabian Peninsula () is an exonym for the peninsula of Southeast Asia that is defined in two ways by the countries of Yemen and Saudi Arabia. Historically it is the eastern part of Middle East. The name Arabian Peninsula is derived from the Arabian Peninsula, itself a portion of the larger Iranian Plateau, which includes Iran, Afghanistan, Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. The peninsula can also refer to the Persian Gulf, that part of the Indian Ocean located off the coasts of Iran and United Arab Emirates.

answer: Washington Naval Conference of 1922 in Washington, D.C., was attended by representatives from eleven governments, including the United States, Japan, and Britain, who were seeking to create a system of naval treaties to regulate the growing number of belligerents whose navies were using and threatening to use naval power against one another. The conference established the principles of the Five-Power Treaty System for preventing naval warfare, a system that would regulate the world's great navies for the next 70 years.

answer: 28 Days (film) is a 2000 American comedy-drama film directed by Andy Weissman, and starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Jennifer Ehle. answer: Dennis Hastert is an American politician, who represented Illinois's 11th congressional district from 1965 until 2007. answer: Caracazo was the name of the general strike and armed rebellion that took place on January 5, 1979 in El Salvador. It was launched to protest a plan for agrarian reform proposed by Salvadorean government, that would have expropriated 85,000 hectares of small farms and redistributed them to peasants. It eventually claimed between 3,000 and 10,000 lives, and the death toll is estimated at 15,000.

answer: Shallow Hal is a 1998 American comedy film starring Owen Wilson. It is the first film in which Wilson co-starred with co-writer and director Peter Segal, who previously wrote with Wilson in Swingers. The film was released to negative reviews from critics who found its plot and jokes stale and unfunny. answer: Ballet Shoes (film) is a 2003 Brazilian dance musical film directed, choreographed, and co-written by Marcelo Gomes. It stars Bruno Gagliasso, Fernanda Montenegro, Vera Silva, Lourdinho Marques, Ivan de Almeida, Carla Camurati and Fernanda Lima. It follows a young girl (Andréa Beltrão, a.k.a. "Anette") from Bahia's impoverished north to Rio de Janeiro's samba- and pengode-inspired elite. At a dance rehearsal she meets a dapper young man (Fernanda Montenegro) who teaches her how to dance the péndulo and how to speak, and to whom she dedicates the song she performs. After failing to find her father, "Anette" turns rebellious and goes after the mysterious man. The plot bears some resemblances to a story in Alexandre Dumas, père's The Three Musketeers.

topic: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
answer: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a 2016 American superhero film loosely based on DC Comics' Batman character, Batman, and also features Superman. It is the upcoming conclusion of the DC Extended Universe, as well as a standalone film that exists in a "shared universe" with the previous films Man of Steel, The Dark Knight, and The Dark Knight Rises. The film was produced by Warner Bros. Pictures, it was directed by Zack Snyder, with the screenplay written by Chris Terrio, and stars Henry Cavill, Ben Affleck, Gal Gadot, Amy Adams, Laurence Fishburne, Diane Lane, Jesse Eisenberg, Jeremy Irons, Holly Hunter, Tao Okamoto, Callan McAuliffe, and Russell Crowe. The film follows Bruce Wayne (Affleck) in the months following his return from a five-year absence, as he prepares to make the first steps of his self-appointed career as a vigilante, who fights crime in Gotham City. He uncovers a conspiracy by Lex Luthor and the local metahuman population, and forms an alliance with Lois Lane and Superman (Cavill) to combat their common foe.

answer: Archimedes (Greek Αρχιμέδων, Arímidon, "the leader") was a Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, physicist, inventor, astronomer, and geologist.
