USER:
answer: United States Environmental Protection Agency is a non-partisan American federal governmental agency. Founded in 1970, it was established under the US Congress, under the Office of the US House of Representatives, at an authorized establishment of 2,100 full-time employees. However, its budget was cut from US$1 billion to US$664 million between 1988 and 1991. The agency is the lead institution responsible for protecting air, water, and land in the US and is charged with cleaning up dangerous chemicals such as PCBs. It coordinates EPA activities and programs that protect the nation's air and water under federal statutes administered by the Secretary of the United States. With an annual budget of US$8.2 billion, the agency is the largest single operator of chemical facilities in the US. The EPA is the only institution with the power to enforce federal chemical safety and drinking water regulations, including the Safe Drinking Water Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and the Clean Air Act. Since 2000, the agency has been headed by chemical industry analyst and former chemical lobbyist Mike Leavitt, holding the position from 2001 to 2004 while he simultaneously served as governor of Utah.

answer: Dany Rigoulot is a French actor who has appeared in over 80 films with several actresses. He has had a long career as a leading man; after becoming one of François Truffaut's favorite actors, he was nominated for two César Awards. In addition, he has garnered a reputation for playing a male icon in female roles, from the leading lady in Truffaut's Les Quatre Cents Coups to the role of Dr. Cournoyer in Agnès Varda’s Vagabonde (1985). Rigoulot was born in 1948 in Paris. A graduate of the acting school in Villejuif (where, among others, he met Truffaut and Jacques Rivette), he debuted in the film of Bernard Blier's Les Bonnes Femmes in 1970. In 1972, while continuing to work as an actor, he also began a career as a fashion model, which he maintained throughout the years. His modeling work soon led him to a role in Jacques Rivette's first feature film Cézanne's Widow in 1975.

topic: The Waterboy, Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)
answer: The Waterboy is a 1995 comedy film starring Owen Wilson and Mike Judge, from the screenplay written by John Hughes. Judge was inspired to adapt Hughes' screenplay by an anecdote he heard his roommate, Scott Coffey, tell about a trip Hughes took to a lake near his home. The film, produced by Hughes and Judge, was the first movie Hughes made since 1989's Curb Your Enthusiasm (which Judge executive-produced). The cast includes Josh Brolin, Tom Cavanagh, David Koechner, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, Jason Lee, and Janeane Garofalo.

answer: Oliver Reed (18 September 1931 – 3 August 1999) was an English actor. Reed's career spanned over seven decades, during which he appeared in some of the most important films of the 20th century. He is the third actor in history to receive a posthumous Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor, for his role in Peter Bogdanovich's Murder on the Orient Express. USER:
answer: Stagira (ancient city) is a large city located in the northern part of the Peloponnesian Peninsula. It was the capital city of Magnesia during the 6th cent. BC and home of an influential tyrant. According to Xenophon, Stagira controlled the surrounding region through "the most powerful government of any in Greece", and its king was the first of Greece to use silver currency when he minted coins for the population of Magnesia. His coinage was based on the image of a sphinx; the sphinx was the symbol of Athena, and the sphinx was regarded as her image, thus symbolising that the city was ruled by Athena. After Alexander the Great conquered the region, he renamed the city after himself, declaring it "Alexandria". After the Achaean League was formed by the cities of Achaea in 338 BC, the city was renamed Stagira for "the first".  Stagira has been listed by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) on its World Heritage List, as Ancient Stagira and Ancient Messene.

answer: Gift of the Night Fury is the nineteenth album by Nine Inch Nails, released on March 22, 2014, by TVT Records. It is the follow-up to Ghosts I–IV, and the lead single, "We're in This Together", was released on January 21, 2014. In contrast to the previous album's more aggressive sound, Gift of the Night Fury leans more towards ambient and ambient dub, bringing the album closer to Nine Inch Nails' previous ambient-gothic dance-punk style. It is also the band's first record to not feature drummer Chris Vrenna, with Josh Eustis taking over.

USER:
answer: Tony Blair, Baron Blair of Kipswood (born 15 June 1953), is a life peer in the UK House of Lords. After being elected as the leader of the Labour Party in 1994, Blair became the first British prime minister since his party's leader in 1922, Stanley Baldwin, to serve a full first term in 1997. He was elected the Prime Minister for the second time in May 2006, as the leader of the largest party in parliament. Prior to the 2005 general election, Blair was widely regarded as being one of the world's most influential and powerful statesmen. He also has close ties with the International Monetary Fund, acting on its behalf in negotiations with the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), which has sometimes been described as the "central bank for central banks". In April 2013, after eight years in government, Blair became one of the first Labour politicians to resign as an MP.

USER:
answer: United States is a common usage of the state of the Americas, especially when it is being referred to as in a plural sense, to refer to the entire continental region. It is an official name in English since the adoption of a formal definition and geographic boundaries in Section Two, Article Two of the United States Constitution, commonly referred to as "the Articles of Confederation". Prior to the adoption of this document, many colonists used various terms, such as "the United States of America", simply describing what they assumed to be the combined states of North and South America. However, by the time of the American Revolution, the expression "the United States" became associated with the new nation.

USER:
answer: Dayton Agreement was a joint communiqué issued at the end of the Second World War to restore Czechoslovakia's independence and secure its peaceful integration into the Soviet Union. It was signed on August 2, 1945 by representatives of the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, and France at Štúrovo and concluded at Teheran, Iran, on October 18, 1945 to lay out the principles for the creation of the United Nations. The principles defined the borders between the Soviet Union, the People's Republic of Poland and the Czechoslovak Soviet Socialist Republic; the status of German-populated territories previously part of Czechoslovakia; the borders of the future states; the status of the ethnic Germans living in Poland; and a temporary military boundary between Czechoslovakia and the western USSR.

answer: Prince (musician) was an American musical artist and songwriter, whose creativity and musical genius were unmatched, yet few knew anything about him. He released 14 studio albums, with one more to go until the release of Piano & A Microphone on April 21, 2016. With his death in April 2016, Prince left an unparalleled legacy of music for millions of people all around the world.

topic: Rick and Morty, Dan Harmon, Justin Roiland
answer: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated sitcom created by Justin Roiland and created by Dan Harmon and Roiland. The 30-minute series premiered on November 28, 2013 on Adult Swim. It centres on the meandering adventures of a blue hedgehog (voiced by Roiland) and a yellow anthropomorphic "dino-mite" (voiced by Justin Timberlake) who can talk to each other telepathically in an imagined multiverse containing several alien planets (Roiland has stated that he sees Rick and Morty as a cartoon that "goes hard R"; the title being a parody of a line in the show) in a world where humans have been replaced by robots and the universe is run by a maniacal interdimensional tyrant (voiced by Timberlake, also known for his roles in television series Friends and Saturday Night Live) who frequently punishes planets in the universe for his evil acts and who has created the "Rixty-One", a portal gun which grants its user's wishes. The plot is driven by Rixty-Two's misadventures, while Morty and Rick are typically forced into various situations requiring them to use science, time travel, alternate dimensions, alternate universes, a giant robot, and a Rick Potion that allows them to fly.

USER:
answer: Hypothyroidism is a clinical condition that is caused by inadequate or low production of thyroid hormones. In the majority of cases it affects the thyroid gland causing it to slowly stop producing sufficient amounts of thyroid hormones. While this process takes several years, symptoms can affect the body almost from the onset. The most common symptoms of Hypothyroidism include high cholesterol, depression, fatigue, anxiety, obesity, cold intolerance, constipation, increased appetite, muscle weakness, and infertility. An abnormal heart rate, high blood pressure, and heart palpitations are also frequent side symptoms and complications.

topic: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song)
answer: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song) is a song by American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars from his debut album Unorthodox Jukebox (2012). It was released as the album's lead single on July 17, 2012. The song was later included on its official soundtrack. At the 53rd Grammy Awards on February 10, 2014, Mars won the Grammy Award for Record of the Year for the song, while it also won both a Best Pop Solo Performance and Record of the Year awards. The song has become Mars's fifth number one song on the Billboard Hot 100.

USER:
answer: Mary Marvel was a fictional heroine created in 1941 by the writer Max Elbaum. She has been called the first major American superheroine, and in her own right, as the first American "supergirl." She inspired many imitations. The character was created for the comic book Marvel Comics #15 (Aug. 1941), based on the earlier "Tammie" feature in the All-American Comics Magazine. She was part of an expanding lineup of costumed characters that the company was launching as part of its war effort during World War II. The character was created by Max Elbaum, who also created the Golden Age superhero the Atom. In the early 1940s, she was called Tammie, a name she used in her earlier comics. When comics characters were renamed for the United States' wartime propaganda, Mary's name was changed to Marvel. To avoid potential confusion with the similarly named character Marvel Comics first created in 1939, Max Elbaum chose to call his creation "Marvel" as he wanted the name to sound like a girl's name. After the company changed to Timely Comics, Marvel began to appear as part of its lineup of characters. Her costume of a short skirt and a belt with a buckle that became popular was later used by Captain Marvel comic books. At first, Mary Marvel appeared wearing the same costume as her Atom-era predecessor Tammie, but her costume was cut shorter, revealing more of her legs. After the war, the name "Mary Marvel" was revived for a second female superheroine.

USER:
answer: Prison Break is an American television action-drama series created and produced by Paul Simms and Robert Mark Kamen, that first aired on the American Broadcasting Company (ABC) from March 19 to April 23, 2005. The series features an ensemble cast portraying diverse characters who are all locked up in or trying to escape from a fictional maximum-security prison in the American Midwest, and the inmates, guards and other prison workers who are trying to free them. The series also shows different perspectives of inmates' families and their personal lives before and during incarceration with their reactions to news regarding their incarceration. The series premiered on Mondays at 9:00 pm, airing on Tuesdays at 9:01 pm when ABC temporarily replaced Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? due to the death of its co-creator (Dick Clark). As a result of the ratings surge, the series moved back to its regular time of 9:00 pm on April 23, 2005. In April 2009, the series moved back to its original time slot of Thursdays at 9:00 pm. The series is a spin-off from the original FOX series, and was first broadcast in Australia on the Nine Network, Canada on City in 2005 and on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in 2008. An accompanying feature film, directed by Paul T. Scheuring, was released in 2005 by Universal Pictures. In 2005, TV Guide Magazine ranked the show in the #1 show for the 2005-2006 season. In January 2006, Prison Break made history as the first-ever cable TV series to air on all four major US networks at the same time. In the UK it premiered on the Sky 1 channel on November 13, 2005, and was broadcast on Channel 5 in the second half of 2006. In Canada, the show began airing on W Network on July 26, 2005 and ended on September 3, 2007.Foetal and maternal circulating and ovarian hormone binding protein (FABP) and alpha 2M glycoprotein (A1GP) in serum after elective Caesarean section.

answer: Cary Grant was an American actor who was a box office star and one of the most popular stars of the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s. He is often regarded as one of the greatest and most versatile actors in Hollywood history. He began his career in silent films, achieving fame for his comic and dramatic roles, and cemented his status in the late thirties with seven Academy Award nominations in just five years. He was Hollywood's top male star until the arrival of his lifelong friend and collaborator Randolph Scott in 1934. For 20 years, he was Hollywood's top leading man, with his career beginning the Golden Age of Hollywood and continuing through the transition to talkies and until he retired in 1959. His talent, charisma, and ability to connect with audiences made him one of the greatest stars of all time and he is a member of the National Film Registry.

answer: Rogue (comics) is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics. answer: Haifa is an Israeli municipality in north-central coastal Tel-Aviv District. Haifa is one of three cities in Israel with a Jewish majority (the other 2 being Tel Aviv and Petah Tikva). The name of the city is Hebrew for "city of peace". Haifa is also widely known in the world as the birthplace of the Arab-Israeli Yishuv or Jewish community in prestate Israel, who founded modern Israel in 1948. The city is at the northwestern coast of the country. It lies on one of the major seaports of Israel, the port of Haifa is situated on the northern tip of Haifa Bay. The Bay has two bays, the larger one of which is at the south of the port. The Port of Haifa is Israel's largest harbor, as of 2012, with its  of enclosed commercial area, and a  terminal for handling containers.

answer: Hot (Mel B album) is the debut studio album by Irish singer and songwriter Mel B. The album was released on November 10, 1992. After moving to London to pursue a singing career, Mel B was discovered by an unnamed dance producer. After recording a few demos, and being offered a contract by a German record label, she released her first album, Hot. Following its eventual commercial success, Mel B signed an international deal with Virgin Records in 1993. Hot was an immediate hit in the UK peaking at number thirteen. The album was successful and sold multi-platinum around the world, and is certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America, gold by the British Phonographic Industry, platinum in Canada, and Australia and has sold over 7 million copies worldwide. Hot spawned five singles: "I Should Be So Lucky", "Finally Found Someone", "If We Stay Together", "You're the One" and "It Doesn't Matter Anymore".

answer: 19th G7 summit (French: Troisième sommet G7 à Rome, "Third G7 Summit in Rome"), also known as the Rome Summit, was a summit of the leaders of the seven wealthiest advanced economies in the world. topic: Back to the Future Part II
answer: Back to the Future Part II is a film by Robert Zemeckis and Bob Gale, released in October 1990. It is the second sequel to Zemeckis and Gale's 1983 film Back to the Future; the film also features Celine Dion as Lorraine Baines. The film was a major hit, taking in a total of $485 million worldwide, on a budget of $43 million and grossing $235 million in North America. Back to the Future Part Two received generally positive reviews; some critics deemed it "the most successful sequel ever made". It earned a rare nomination at the 57th Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects.

topic: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (film)
answer: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (film) is a 2016 American horror film directed by Tim Burton and written by C. Robert Cargill. It stars Eva Green, Rafi the Dog, Asa Butterfield, and Terence Stamp, and tells the story of Emma Bloom, a sixteen-year-old girl whose new family moves to the titular island so her grandfather Professor F. R. Peregrine will build a "special" orphanage. Upon arriving on the island, Emma encounters the peculiar creatures that inhabit the island's mysterious environs — creatures who are living human beings trapped in peculiar, insect-like bodies — and she helps them escape. The film was critically well-received, received positive overall reviews, and was a box office success, grossing over $330 million worldwide.

answer: Foo Fighters (sometimes stylized as FooFighters) is an American musical duo that consists of Dave Grohl (lead vocals, percussion) and the late drummer Chris Cornell. The group was formed in 1994 when Grohl met with former Soundgarden vocalist and drummer Jeff Young to perform with a new band and to continue a brief collaboration begun in 1989, which they called Scream. The band has since released ten studio albums: Foo Fighters (1995), There Is Nothing Left (1998), Under a Black Moon (1999), The Colour and the Shape (2002), There Is Nothing Left (Reissue) (2004), In Your Honor (2005), Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace (2007), Wasting Light (2012), Sonic Highways (2014) and HAIM (2016).

answer: The Twilight Saga (film series) is an American film series directed by Summit Entertainment and New Moon director Catherine Hardwicke. Beginning with The Twilight Saga: New Moon, Summit Entertainment distributed the series to film exhibitors in North America; when released in 2009, the three-film series became the highest-grossing DVD release in history, until that record was broken by The Dark Knight Rises (2012). Summit Entertainment released the The Twilight Saga: Eclipse on 4 December 2010 and released the final installment of the series a year later, The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1. Summit subsequently retained distribution and home video rights of the series, which are now held by Lionsgate. Each film has grossed more than $280 million in box-office receipts, and all three films were also nominated at the 82nd Academy Awards for Best Picture, although no awards were won. At the 2011 MTV Movie Awards, The Twilight Saga: Eclipse became the fifth-most-nominated movie and the first ever franchise movie to be nominated in all of the 11 pre-established categories. The first two installments of the series were released directly-to-video in 2005. Summit Entertainment released the first two films in one box set, simply titled "Twilight". For the Twilight Saga: Eclispse Blu-ray/DVD Release, Summit also released the director's cut of the film for the first time.

answer: The Homesman (2015) is a 2015 American drama film written and directed by Gillian Anderson and starring Anderson and Tommy Lee Jones. answer: Ice hockey is a contact team sport played in a rink, between two teams of skaters and players who use sticks to check and hit one another into the boards, in an attempt to score by pushing a puck into their opponent's net and earning a goal. Each team has one goalkeeper, who is the last line of defense and wears a mask over their face and protects the "heart of the net" (the center of the ice) from being hit by the puck and the opposing team's sticks and skates. It is known by a number of variations of the word "hockey", such as ice hockey, ice hockey, ice hockey, ice hockey-hockey, and hockey-hockey. It originated in Canada and is the most popular sport in Canada and in many countries in the Northern hemisphere, particularly in areas that are affected by the "polar vortex" or polar jet stream.

answer: The Dark Knight (film) is a 2008 film based on the novel of the same name by novelist Thomas Harris, and directed by Christopher Nolan. The film version stars Christian Bale, Heath Ledger, Kim Basinger, Maggie Gyllenhaal and Aaron Eckhart and was released by Warner Bros. on August 16, 2008. It is the third film of Nolan's Batman trilogy, following Batman Begins (2005) and The Dark Knight (2008). The film tells a continuation of Batman Begins' storyline ending with events of The Dark Knight (2008) and Batman Begins' origin story. It follows the Bruce Wayne's retirement from patrolling the streets as Batman, leaving the superhero role to his ward, Bruce Wayne's friend and employee at Wayne Enterprises, Harvey "Harvey" Dent. Dent is then brutally murdered when thugs led by the Joker explode a rigged exploding-barrel water park ride, causing Dent's skull to be fragmented into two halves by a falling section of the ride's cable. This in turn convinces the city to turn to Dent's colleague, district attorney Harvey Dent, and his political associates to clean up Gotham's streets from the chaos caused by the Joker's gang. The film was generally well-reviewed by critics and audiences and grossed over $543 million. At the 82nd Academy Awards, The Dark Knight won the Academy Award for Best Picture, the first time a superhero movie has been nominated for that award.

topic: Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago), Chicago
answer: Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago) is a science museum in Chicago, Illinois, America. It opened in November 2003. It's a joint venture between Chicago’s Museum of Science and Industry and Adler Planetarium. The museum has a collection of over five million objects. Museum of Science and Industry is located in Lake Shore Drive at Michigan Avenue. It is an anchor tenant of the Chicago Cultural Center. It is the ninth largest science museum in the world.

answer: Punisher is a comic book character that features in Marvel Comics' Daredevil and Spider-Man comic book lines. Frank Miller's 1986 graphic novel The Dark Knight Returns, in which the Punisher appears in the future, is the seminal story introducing the character in the public imagination. The Frank Miller Dark Knight Returns have been cited by some critics as the best of the Dark Knight series; for example, Dark Knight and Superman: The Animated Series writer Paul Dini stated Miller's Punisher "strikes just the right balance between brutal and brutalized", and TV Tropes characterizes the character as "a grim and uncompromising hero".M.A.P.I.D.S.A.D.P.

answer: Hamlet (1990 film) or Hamlet: Revenge is a 1990 film film by Joel and Ethan Coen starring Tim Curry. Shot in 1991, it tells the tale of Hamlet set in the early 1990s on an ocean liner called the Queen Elizabeth 2, which has been hijacked by pirates and is heading towards the Caribbean. The plot, characters and dialogue are not only modeled after a Shakespearean tragedy (specifically, a performance of the play by William Shakespeare of the same name) but are also drawn from the musical Hair (by the composer Galt MacDermot) and its Broadway musical version, Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical.  The film was remade with the same title in 2002.

topic: The New Adventures of Old Christine
answer: The New Adventures of Old Christine (formerly known as The New Christine) is an Australian television sitcom, which began airing on April 2, 2007 on the Nine Network. The show stars Laurie Miller (formerly of All Saints) in the title role of an emotionally insecure divorced woman. The plot revolves around the relationships she forms with men she meets (who are played by comedians Dave Hughes and Matt McGuire). The show was co-created, written and created by Sarah Kay (All Saints) and has also been produced by Kay's real-life husband Andrew Knight who plays the part of Dr Michael. The New Christine is a spin-off of the much-loved All Saints series of the late 1990s.

USER:
answer: John Glenn (November 18, 1921 – December 16, 2016) was an American aviator, astronaut, and politician. Considered to have been one of the greatest U.S. astronauts in history, he is the first American to orbit Earth and one of the last surviving members of NASA's original Mercury 7. He was also the oldest living astronaut and first American to orbit. A member of the U.S. Navy since 1942, he flew 77 combat missions as a Navy Grumman TBF Avenger in World War II and the Korean War and was a central figure in the astronaut corps during the Cold War space race. Glenn flew on three Mercury missions, two of those as Commander, and was assigned as Command Pilot for the maiden orbital spaceflight of the Mercury capsule Friendship 7. As the oldest alumnus of the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland (Class of 1942), and one of fewer than three hundred Americans qualified to be an astronaut, his many achievements made him a symbol of the space age. While flying his third space mission, in February 1962, Glenn became the second American in space. He went on to fly the Mercury space capsule on two extended spaceflights, the Mercury-Atlas 6 mission in orbital flight number 22 in April 1962 and in orbital flight number 24 seven months later. He was selected by NASA as the United States' first astronaut in the Mercury program, launched on his second mission as Commander of Friendship 7, and became the sixth American in space aboard Friendship 7. His first orbital spaceflight, Mercury orbital flight number 21, occurred ten days later, but lasted only one orbit. Glenn's third and final orbital spaceflight mission was designated orbital flight number 24 to allow the Mercury spacecraft to make multiple orbits, which required Glenn to be in the spacecraft for almost a full 24-hour period. The Soviet Union had recently announced an end to any manned spaceflight program, and Glenn was on NASA's highest priority mission. Glenn made the second-to-last Gemini program spaceflight in October 1966, a twenty-hour transcontinental pilot to-and-fro flight on the Gemini 10 mission. He was in the first group of astronauts to fly the newly developed NASA Gemini spacecraft, which became the mainstay space vehicle for NASA's human spaceflight program until the end of the Space Shuttle program in 2011. The most recent orbiter was named after him.

Born in Londrina on 15 July 1988, the Brazilian-born Costa had been playing for Vasco da Gama until he signed for Atlético Clube de Portugal, the former club that loaned him to Vasco da Gama, for a reported 25 million reals (US$18,000,000) fee on 29 December 2008. Atlético Clube de Portugal gave him a further 5.8 million reals (US$3,700,000) for a clause in the contract. He won the 2003 Brasil Futebol Championship title with his first club Vasco da Gama, and the 2010 Brasil Futebol Championship with Atlético Clube de Portugal. In February 2014, Costa signed for La Liga club, Atlético Madrid, for a transfer fee of 25 million euros. In his second season at the club, he helped them win their first La Liga title. In January 2016, Madrid acquired him for €40 million (US$51 million), making him Atlético Madrid's most expensive signing.

answer: The Big Trail is a 1939 American western film starring Roy Rogers as an English nobleman out to save a town from evil Indians. answer: Southport, Cheshire, England, on the North Sea Coast, has long been a seaside resort, beginning in Roman times, and becoming a popular and fashionable place in the early 18th century. The famous poet, playwright, and satirist Ben Jonson published a poem about Southport in 1620. In 1807, it emerged for a period as a fashionable and exclusive place of residence, with notable residents including Lord Byron, William Wordsworth, and Lord Byron's half-brother. The first public health regulations were introduced in 1866, and by 1874 a tram service linked the resort to the town centre of Stockton. Southport expanded into a major resort during the 1970s and 1980s. Tourism now accounts for over half of the town's total income and visitor numbers. Its attractions include a traditional harbour, an 18th-century suspension footbridges over the sand dunes, an aquarium, and the Northgate Towers. The "fantastic beach" has been voted Britain's best and one of Europe's best, but the beaches are generally much narrower and less popular than those on the east coast of England.

Rossiya; IPA: [ˈɾosiˈja]) is a country in northern Eurasia—bordering on both the Pacific Ocean and the Arctic Ocean as well as on European Russia as well as Belarus. A federal semi-presidential republic, Russia covers 11 time zones on the eastern half of the large continent of Eurasia, stretching west to west for about 9,780 kilometres (6,093 mi) along the Eurasian land mass, from the Atlantic Ocean in the west to the Pacific Ocean in the east, and from the Arctic Ocean to the Black Sea in the north. USER:
answer: Taiwan (/tʃɑˈnaʃ/; pinyin: táiwā) is an island country in East Asia. In a 2010 Gallup poll, Taiwan ranked seventh most-admired in the world. It is the only island within the Asia-Pacific region not entirely located within a continent or other major landmasses. The term "East Asian" is also sometimes applied to the area between mainland China to its west, Japan to its north, and South Korea to its east. The largest political divisions of Taiwan are determined by the Civil Code enacted in 1887. The ROC is divided into 25 administrative divisions and four cities, all of which have varying degrees of autonomy. Taiwan has been declared a "Free Port Zone" since the 1980s. Since the late 1990s, China has been aggressively promoting unification with Taiwan. Taiwan's status as a self-governed province of China is no longer the official position of the Beijing government. The position paper on Taiwan from the Foreign ministry of the People's Republic of China states that no one can make the decision about their country's status except the people of the country themselves, and the only solution at present is to maintain the territorial integrity and political status quo of China under the premise of "One Country, Two Systems".

answer: Sarah Palin (born March 18, 1964) is the former Governor of Alaska and former vice-presidential candidate. Prior to her political career, Palin was a sports broadcaster for ESPN, the Alaska Sports Commission and the Alaska Oilers of the Continental Basketball Association. answer: Will Ferrell is an American actor, comedian, film producer, and film director. answer: Performance (film) is a 2000 American black comedy film directed, written, and produced by Paul Thomas Anderson. It is based on the novel The Master of Sex by Eric Ambler, who also contributed the screenplay. The story concerns a man in Los Angeles who hires a woman he meets on an Internet service to be his sexual partner on a trial basis. The film stars Philip Seymour Hoffman, Elisabeth Shue, Robert Downey Jr., and Joaquin Phoenix. Although widely panned by critics, it won three Oscar nominations for Best Original Screenplay, Best Supporting Actor (Phoenix), and Best Supporting Actress (Shue), with Phoenix winning for Best Actor. The film has a 66% rating on Rotten Tomatoes and three stars out of five on Metacritic. Performance is the feature debut of Anderson, who earned a Writers Guild of America nomination for this and two other Anderson projects. Anderson has said he wrote the script as an exercise after taking a year off from writing.
